stream_context.summary: Kaze works on two areas: early-stage layout & visual concept for Course 15 (Space Arcade Rocket) and a detailed re-work of the Bomb-Cap ‘factory’ course. 90 % of the stream is live problem-solving on design ideas, art direction, collision, memory and actor limits.

development_findings.summary: Game scope is locked at 15 main courses; Course 15 is the last to build and the overall project is described as “nearly finished.”
development_findings.quote: Game is nearly finished. We are getting there.

development_findings.summary: Course 15 theme: a Space Arcade inside a giant rocket. Interior will have a spiral shaft with rooms, a black-hole void and platforming over emptiness.
development_findings.quote: A giant rocket that's the casino… inside the rocket there's going to be a spiral thing that goes up… rooms inside the rocket with a black hole at the bottom.

development_findings.summary: Proposed six stars for Course 15 include whack-a-mole, rhythm game, skee-ball cannon, pinball-in-space (Sonic Casino Nights style), and a bit-pipe that jumps through micro-sections of classic Mario 64 levels for contrast.
Three ‘Yoshi Stars’ will be hidden in every main course, functioning like Green Stars in Galaxy.
development_findings.quote: There is going to be three Yoshi stars per main level, which are like green stars in our galaxy.

development_findings.summary: Mario’s entire animation system was overhauled off-stream to make motions ‘much more consistent.’
development_findings.quote: I overhauled Mario's animation system. Mario's animations are now much more consistent.

development_findings.summary: Technical exploration of an additive glow/bloom material failed; decided to scrap and rethink environmental color palette (darker sky, arcade carpet) for Course 15.
Fast64 exporter bug discovered: negative tile shift causes texture to repeat incorrectly. Kaze will file a bug report.
development_findings.quote: Definitely a Fast64 bug, right? I'm not insane here.

development_findings.summary: Severe crashes traced to actor/collision overflow. Kaze prunes collision triangles (from ~8 k to 3.9 k) and raises buffers; suspects bomb-production actors but final root-cause still open.

Bomb-Cap Factory re-work: Biobak’s new geometry adopted. Kaze adds seven-segment timer, overhead lighting, low-gravity boxes, revised treadmills and a mandatory bomb tutorial door so players must blow up a wall before exiting.
development_findings.quote: I want the player to immediately figure out that the bomb can blow stuff up, so I'm just going to put up a wall here.

context_findings.summary: Kaze distrusts contractors; refused to sign for a ‘better internet’ plan after installer lied and left hardware. Reflects his assertive, do-it-yourself attitude.
context_findings.quote: I didn't sign anything… now they have dropped their router into our basement. I'm not paying for that.

context_findings.summary: Philosophy: dislikes performative productivity (making beds) and ‘identity’ activities (listening to classical music to seem smart). Values genuine efficiency.
context_findings.quote: Making your bed is a sign that you're an unproductive person… you're wasting time of your day to make the bed worse.

context_findings.summary: Design stance: avoids gambling connotation; insists Course 15 is an arcade, not a casino.
context_findings.quote: It is an arcade, not a casino. I don't want any gambling in here.

context_findings.summary: Belief that optimal play should also be fun; criticises Pokémon and Yoshi’s Island DS for design that forces sub-optimal play to enjoy.
context_findings.quote: I kind of demand of a game that the act of beating it optimally is fun.

biobak.summary: Originated the ‘rocket in space arcade’ visual concept and provided window-light ‘hit-the-lights’ minigame idea.
Delivered major remodel of Bomb-Cap Factory: new lighting, catwalks, bomb treadmills, overhead-light ceiling; removed cranes; reduced 2 k polygons and one material.

zeina.summary: Personal note: sometimes makes the bed, illustrating overlap of home life and development space.
zeina.quote: Zaina sometimes makes the bed and every time she makes the bed… you made it worse.

key_stories.title: Brainstorming the Space Arcade
key_stories.summary: Kaze free-associates star ideas, visuals and mechanics for Course 15, wrestling with color palette, traversal surfaces and whether to include retro Mario 64 diorama.
key_stories.challenge: Define a coherent final course that feels fresh yet nostalgic.
key_stories.process: Rapid idea listing, chat sparring, live Blender mock-ups, palette tests, and written to-do notes.
key_stories.outcome: Settled on darker skybox, rocket hub, six star concepts, and intention to contrast RTYI art with micro-Mario 64 areas.
key_stories.key_quote: I have too many ideas for this level… but the contrast between Mario 64 levels and RTYI levels is going to be beautiful.

key_stories.title: The Bomb-Cap Factory Rework
key_stories.summary: Biobak submits a large geometry update; Kaze walks through every change, adds code tasks, tweaks visuals and plans a forced tutorial wall.
key_stories.challenge: Integrate new art while ensuring gameplay clarity and performance.
key_stories.process: Live review of blend file, annotations to to-do list (lighting, low gravity, timer), collision trimming, play-testing.
key_stories.outcome: Feature list locked; remaining tasks are collision optimisation and actor crash fix.
key_stories.key_quote: This level should be playable both backwards and forwards, but I still want the player to get immediate feedback: OK, I can blow up walls now.

key_stories.title: The Mysterious Crash
key_stories.summary: Course crashes repeatedly during testing; initial suspicion of collision size then actor overflow.
key_stories.challenge: Game crashes entering factory; no clear error.
key_stories.process: Remove object groups incrementally, increase RAM actor buffers, test on different emulators, identify possible object-count overflow.
key_stories.outcome: Crash narrowed to specific object combinations; full fix pending next stream.
key_stories.key_quote: If this doesn't fix it, we are in shit. Then there is some kind of weird thing going on.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions boxes that halve gravity in factory and rocket level.
questions: How exactly will low-gravity zones be coded on N64 hardware?
Will gravity vary smoothly or be a binary switch?
Any risks of motion sickness or physics bugs?

open_questions.context: Off-stream refactor claimed to make animations ‘much more consistent.’
questions: What technical approach was taken (state machine, interpolation)?
How did it affect ROM-size and performance?

open_questions.context: Kaze asks chat for OST ideas but Badub’s plans aren’t discussed.
questions: What musical direction is planned for the Space Arcade?
How does Badub translate arcade ambience into N64 audio constraints?
Will rhythm-game star use adaptive music?

open_questions.context: Kaze says they will build hub world and Bowser course after Course 15.
questions: What thematic and mechanical goals exist for the hub?
How will the final Bowser fight differ from vanilla?
Timeline and resource allocation for these remaining areas?

open_questions.context: Crashes suggest overflow of actor lists or collision buffers.
questions: What are exact memory ceilings in the decomp engine?
Which new systems (particles, bombs, CRT screens) risk hitting limits?
How will they audit levels to ensure stability on real hardware?

open_questions.context: Kaze insists on ‘no casino’ despite slot-machine style mechanics.
questions: Why the firm stance against gambling imagery?
Were there internal debates on this with team members?
How does this relate to broader design ethics?
